tutorial.title: Dark Mode
tutorial.descriptionContent: Build a theme switcher to activate dark mode for a webpage

executableContent.instructions:
Let's use our knowledge of conditionals to build a webpage with buttons that switch between light, dark and ninja modes.

In this project, we'll add the JavaScript code that changes `label`, `color`, and `image` variables depending on the selected mode.

We've already initialized the variables with some default values. What's left is for you to conditionally update them. Take a look at the code before you continue.

1. `mode` will enable us to switch between the `dark`, `light`, and `ninja` modes that define the look of the UI.
2. `color` stores the background color for the selected mode.
3. `image` stores the path to the image that'll display for the selected mode.
4. `label` informs the user what mode they're currently using.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Since there are three modes, we need to check the value of the mode.

Let's start by creating an `if` statement that checks if the `mode` is `"dark"`.

1. Assemble an `if` statement that checks if the `mode` variable is set to `"dark"`. Leave its code block empty for now.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
The syntax for `if` statement is :
```javascript
if (condition) {<code block>}
```

executableContent.instructions:
Your next task is to check if the `mode` is `"light"`.

1. Add an `else if` statement that runs when `mode` is equal to `"light"`.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
The syntax for `else if` is similar to that of an `if` statement.

The only difference is, you have to write `else if` instead of `if`.

executableContent.instructions:
But what if the `mode` is not `"light"` or `"dark"`? For this situation, let's code an `else` statement.

1. Add an empty `else` statement that runs when `mode` isn't `"light"` or `"dark"`.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
The variables should update differently in each mode.

1. When `mode` is `"dark"`, `color` should update to `"darkSlateBlue"` in the code block.
2. Then update `image` to `"/img/dark-icon.png"`.
3. Finally, update `label` to `"Dark Mode"`.

files.name: script.js

hints.title: Hint
hints.content:
You can change a variable's value simply by assigning a new value to it again.
Make sure to omit the `let` when you reassign a variable.

executableContent.instructions:
Let's also update the variables when the `mode` is `"light"`.

1. When `mode` is `"light"`, `color` should update to `"ghostWhite"`.
2. Then update `image` to `"/img/light-icon.png"`.
3. Finally, update `label` to `"Light Mode"`.

files.name: script.js

executableContent.instructions:
Finally, it's time to update the variables in the `else` statement's code block.

1. In the `else` statement's code block, update `color` to `"dimGray"`.
2. Then update `image` to `"/img/ninja-icon.png"`.
3. Finally, update `label` to `"Ninja Mode"`.

executableContent.instructions:
We will now see your conditional in action.

1. Print the `label` variable in the console, at the end of your code.
